Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Epigenetic, transcriptomic, and behavioral impacts of a maternal signal during wasp caste development
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many studies on humans and rodents have aimed at understanding how maternal care influences the behavior and health of offspring. Because it is hard to separate the effects of maternal behavior itself from effects of the environment, many fundamental questions remain unanswered: To what extent can maternal care itself directly affect the long-term behavior and physiology of offspring? Can maternal care completely or partially overcome environmental stressors? Does maternal care trigger genetic changes in offspring that mediate long-term effects?

Toth and Jeanne will use a new behavioral system to address these questions. Mother paper wasps (Polistes) feed and care for larvae throughout their development. In the process, maternal wasps physically vibrate their larvae by striking their antennae on nest cells. This behavior, which can be simulated using a piezoelectric device, has profound effects on offspring. Vibrated larvae become workers, whereas un-vibrated wasps become queens. This unique system can be used to experimentally dissect how maternal behavior affects offspring.

The researchers will use state-of-the art DNA sequencing methods to characterize what types of genetic changes (e.g. gene activation or chemical DNA modifications) are induced in offspring in response to the interactions of an environmental factor (nutritional stress) and a maternal behavior (vibrations).

This work will provide new information on the extent to which maternal behavior can affect the fate of offspring, how these effects may be modulated by stressors in the environment, and the genetic mechanisms underlying this process. The project will involve the training of a postdoctoral researcher, several undergraduates, and a high school teacher. The results will be disseminated to the scientific community and new insights shared at school and community outreach events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we aimed to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which mothers can shape the developmental fate of their offspring. We used the paper wasp Polistes fuscatus, an excellent model for studying maternal and social behavior. These wasps form small colonies initiated by founding queens. Interestingly, not all offspring of the colony are equal. Those produced early in the season and reared by the queen are all female and become workers, who are typically sterile, short-lived, and carry out the work of the colony.  In contrast, offspring produced later in the season are reared by the workers and are destined to reproduce rather than work—either as males, or as “gynes”— long-lived females who will become the next generation’s queens.

 To learn how wasps produce such unequal daughters, we used this striking divergence in P. fuscatus female developmental fate to study the role of maternal interactions in shaping offspring traits. We found that there are thousands of genes whose levels of expression differ between developing workers and developing gynes, setting them up for possessing vastly different adult physiology and behavior. Further experiments revealed that two components of the founding queen’s treatment of her larvae have profound effects on their development. First, these early season, worker-destined larvae are underfed by the queen. We showed experimentally that restricted feeding alone can lead to the suppression of certain gyne-determining genes, sending larvae on the developmental track to become workers. Second, founding queens frequently drum their antennae on nest cells containing her offspring larvae. Previous work suggested that these vibrational signals lead her daughters to develop little body fat, a worker-like trait. We attached small piezoelectric devices to mid-season wasp nests—those rearing gyne-destined larvae—and programmed them to simulate the vibrations produced by the queen. We found that these vibrations suppressed a different set of gyne-related genes from those responding to low food levels. Still other gyne-related genes were influenced by the combination of low food and vibrations. Thus, both nutritional and tactile maternal influences, plus their interaction, work together to influence the caste fate of offspring.

 These results provide new insights into how the maternal social environment can influence gene activity in developing offspring.  Importantly, these differences in gene activity have the potential to set up different life trajectories for offspring, leading to adults with vastly different physiological and behavioral phenotypes.
